div.head: ADVERTISEMENT.
div.p: THE travels of an Engliſhman throughout Europe, and even in ſome parts of Aſia, to ſoften the ſorrows of the Priſoner, excited in the mind of the Author the ſubject of the following pages, which, formed into a dramatic ſtory, have produced from the Theatre a profit far exeeeding the uſual pecuniary advantages ariſing from a ſucceſsful Comedy.

The uncertainty in what part of the Eaſt the hero of the preſent piece was (at the time it was written) diſpenſing his benevolence, cauſed the Writer, after many reſearches and objections, to fix the ſcene on the iſland of Sumatra, where the Engliſh ſettlement, the ſyſtem of government, and every deſcription of the manners of the people, reconcile the incidents of the Play to the ſtricteſt degree of probability.

lg.l: HOW ſay you, critic Gods Galleries. and you below Pit.
Are you all friends?—or here—and there—a foe?
Come to protect your literary trade,
Which Mrs. Scribble dares again invade—
But know you not—in all the fair ones do,
'Tis not to pleaſe themſelves alone—but you.
Then who ſo churliſh, or ſo cynic grown,
Would wiſh to change a ſimper for a frown?
Or who ſo jealous of their own dear quill,
Would point the paragraph her fame to kill?
• et ſuch there are, in this all-ſcribbling town,
And men of letters too—of ſome renown,
Who ſicken at all merit but their own.
But ſure 'twere more for Wit's—for Honour's ſake,
To make the Drama's race—the give and take.
My hint I ſee's approv'd—ſo pray begin it,
And praiſe us—roundly for the good things in it,
Nor let ſeverity our faults expoſe,
When godlike Homer's ſelf was known to doze.
But of the piece—Methinks I hear you hint,
Some dozen lines or more ſhould give the tint—
"Tell how Sir John with Lady Betty's maid
"Is caught intriguing at a maſquerade;
"Which Lady Betty, in a jealous fit,
"Reſents by flirting with Sir Ben—the cit.
"Whoſe three-feet ſpouſe, to modiſh follies bent,
"Miſtakes a ſix-feet Valet—for a Gent.
"Whilſt Miſs, repugnant to her Guardian's plan,
"Elopes in Breeches with her fav'rite man."
Such are the hints we read in Roſcius' days,
By way of Prologue uſhered in their plays.
But we, like Miniſters and cautious ſpies,
In ſecret meaſures think—the merit lies.
Yet ſhall the Muſe thus far unveil the plot—
This play was tragi-comically got,
Thoſe ſympathetic ſorrows to impart
Which harmonize the feelings of the heart;
And may at leaſt this humble merit boaſt,
A ſtructure founded on fair Fancy's coaſt.
With you it reſts that judgement to proclaim,
Which in the world muſt raiſe or ſink it's fame.
Yet ere her judges ſign their laſt report,
'Tis you [to the boxes] muſt recommend her to the Court;
Whoſe ſmiles, like Cynthia, in a winter's night,
Will cheer our wand'rer with a gleam of light.

div.head: SUCH THINGS ARE. A PLAY. IN FIVE ACTS.
SCENE I. A Parlour at Sir Luke Tremor's.
div.stage: Enter Sir Luke, followed by Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I TELL you, Madam, you are two and thirty.

sp.speaker: Lady Tremor.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, did not you come over from England exactly ſixteen years ago?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not ſo long.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Have not we been married the tenth of next April ſixteen years?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not ſo long.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Did you not come over the year of the great Eclipſe? anſwer me that.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I don't remember it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
But I do—and ſhall remember it as long as I live—the firſt time I ſaw you, was in the garden of the Dutch Envoy; you were looking through a glaſs at the ſun—I immediately began to make love to you, and the whole affair was
ſettled while the eclipſe laſted—juſt one hour eleven minutes, and three ſeconds.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what is all this to my age?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Becauſe I know you were at that time near ſeventeen—and without one qualification except your youth—and not being a Mullatto.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke, Sir Luke, this is not to be borne—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Oh! yes—I forgot—you had two letters of recommendation, from two great families in England.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Letters of recommendation!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes; your character—that, you know, is all the fortune we poor Engliſhmen, ſituated in India, expect with a wife who croſſes the ſea at the hazard of her life, to make us happy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And what but our characters would you have us bring? Do you ſuppoſe any lady ever came to India, who brought along with her, friends, or fortune?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my dear—and what is worſe—ſhe ſeldom leaves them behind, either.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No matter, Sir Luke—but if I delivered to you a good character—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear you did—and if you were to aſk me for it again, I can't ſay I could give it you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How uncivil! how unlike are your manners to the manners of my Lord Flint.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Ay—you are never ſo happy as when you have an opportunity of expreſſing your admiration of him—a diſagreeable, nay, a very dangerous man—one is never ſure of one's ſelf in his preſence—he carries every thing he hears to the miniſters of our ſuſpicious Sultan—and I feel my head ſhake whenever I am in his company.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How different does his Lordſhip appear to me—to me he is all politeſſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Politeſſe! how ſhou'd you underderſtand what is real politeſſe? You know your education was very much confined.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And if it was confined——I beg, Sir Luke, you will one time or other ceaſe theſe reflections—you know they are what I can't bear! [walks about in a paſſion.] pray, does not his Lordſhip continually aſſure me, I might be taken for a Counteſs, were it not for a certain little groveling toſs I have caught with my head—and a certain little confined hitch in my walk? both which I learnt of you—learnt by looking ſo much at you.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And now if you don't take care, by looking ſo much at his Lordſhip, you may catch ſome of his defects.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know of very few he has.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I know of many—beſides thoſe he aſſumes.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Aſſumes!!——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes; do you ſuppoſe he is as forgetful as he pretends to be? no, no—but becauſe he is a favourite with the Sultan, and all our great men at court, he thinks it genteel or convenient to have no memory—and yet I'll anſwer for it, he has one of the beſt in the univerſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I don't believe your charge.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, though he forgets his appointments with his tradeſmen, did you ever hear of his forgetting to go to court when a place was to be diſpoſed of? Did he ever make a blunder, and ſend a bribe to a man out of power? Did he ever forget to kneel before the Prince of this Iſland—or to look in his highneſs's preſence like the ſtatue of Patient-reſignation in humble expectation?—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear, Sir Luke——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
Sent from his own country in his very infancy, and brought up in the different
courts of petty, arbitrary Princes here in Aſia; he is the ſlave of every great man, and the tyrant of every poor one.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: "Petty Princes!"—'tis well his highneſs our Sultan does not hear you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: 'Tis well he does not—don't you repeat what I ſay—but you know how all this fine country is harraſſed and laid waſte by a ſet of Princes, Sultans, as they ſtyle themſelves, and I know not what—who are for ever calling out to each other "that's mine," and "that's mine;"—and "you have no buſineſs here"—and "you have no buſineſs there"—and "I have buſineſs every where;" [Strutting] then "give me this,"—and "give me that;" and "take this, and take that."

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A very elegant deſcription truly.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, you know 'tis all matter of fact—and Lord Flint, brought up from his youth amongſt theſe people, has not one trait of an Engliſhman about him—he has imbibed all this country's cruelty, and I dare ſay wou'd mind no more ſeeing me hung up by my thumbs—or made to dance upon a red-hot gridiron——

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That is one of the tortures I never heard of!—O! I ſhou'd like to ſee that of all things!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes—by keeping this man's company, you'll ſoon be as cruel as he is—he will teach you every vice—a conſequential—grave—dull—and yet with that degree of levity, that dares to pay his addreſſes to a woman, even before her huſband's face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Did not you ſay, this minute, his Lordſhip had not a trait of his own country about him?—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, well—as you ſay, that laſt is a trait of his own country.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Lord Flint.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: My Lord, I am extremely glad to ſee you—we were juſt mentioning your name.—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Were you, indeed, Madam? You do me great honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my Lord—no great honour.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir Luke.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: But, I aſſure you, my Lord, what I ſaid, did myſelf a great deal of honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and I'll acquaint your Lordſhip what it was.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Pulling her aſide]
sp.p: Why, you wou'd not inform againſt me ſure! Do you know what would be the conſequence? My head muſt anſwer it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Luke, I inſiſt upon knowing.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [To ber]
sp.p: Huſh—huſh——no, my Lord, pray excuſe me—your Lordſhip perhaps may think what I ſaid did not come trom my heart; and I aſſure you, upon my honour, it did.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, yes—that I am ſure it did.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am extremely obliged to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, no, my Lord, not at all—not at all.— [aſide to her.] I'll be extremely obliged to you, if you will hold your tongue—Pray, my Lord, are you engaged out to dinner to-day? for her Ladyſhip and I dine out.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, and we ſhould be happy to find your Lordſhip of the party.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: "Engaged out to dinner"?—egad very likely—very likely—but if I am—I have poſitively forgotten where.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: We are going to—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
No—I think (now you put me in mind
of it) I think I have company to dine with me—I am either going out to dinner, or have company to dine with me; but I really can't tell which—however, my people know——but I can't call to mind.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Perhaps your Lordſhip has dined; can you recollect that?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No, no—I have not dined——what's o'clock?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Perhaps, my Lord, you have not breakfaſted.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: O, yes, I've breakfaſted—I think ſo—but upon my word theſe things are very hard to remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: They are indeed, my Lord—and I wiſh all my family wou'd entirely forget them.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What did your Ladyſhip ſay was o'clock?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Exactly twelve, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Bleſs me! I ought to have been ſome where elſe then—an abſolute engagement.—I have broke my word—a poſitive appointment.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Shall I ſend a ſervant?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No, no, no, no—by no means—it can't be helped now—and they know my unfortunate failing—beſides, I'll beg their pardon, and I truſt that will be ample ſatistaction.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are very good, my Lord, not to leave us.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I cou'd not think of leaving you ſo ſoon, Madam—the happineſs I enjoy here is ſuch—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And very likely were your Lordſhip to go away now, you might never recollect to come again.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A Gentleman, Sir, juſt come from on board an Engliſh veſſel, ſays, he has letters to preſent to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Shew him in— [Exit Servant.] He has brought his character too, I ſuppoſe—and left it behind, too, I ſuppoſe.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Twineall, in a faſhionable undreſs.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Sir Luke, I have the honour of preſenting to you, [Gives letters] one from my Lord Cleland—one from Sir Thomas Shoeſtring—one from Colonel Fril.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Aſide]
sp.p: Who in the name of wonder have my friends recommended?— [reads while Lord Flint and the Lady talk apart] No—as I live, he is a gentleman, and the ſon of a Lord— [going to Lady Tremor.] My dear, that is a gentleman, notwithſtanding his appearance—don't laugh—but let me introduce you to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A gentleman! certainly—I did not look at him before—but now I can perceive it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
Mr. Twineall, give me leave to introduce Lady Tremor to you, and my Lord Flint—this, my Lord, is the Honourable Mr. Twineall from England, who will do me the favour to remain in my houſe, till he is ſettled to his mind in ſome poſt here. [They bow.] I beg your pardon, Sir, for the ſomewhat cool reception Lady Tremor and I gave you at firſt—but I dare ſay her Ladyſhip was under the ſame miſtake as myſelf—and I muſt own I took you at firſt fight for ſomething very different from the perſon you prove to be—for really no Engliſh ſhips have arrived in this harbour for
theſe five years paſt, and the dreſs of us Engliſh gentlemen is ſo much altered fince that time—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But, I hope, Sir Luke, if it is, the alteration meets with your approbation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O! to be ſure—it is extremely elegant and becoming.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, I don't doubt but you think ſo; for I remember you uſed to make your favourite monkey wear juſt ſuch a jacket, when he went out a viſiting.

sp.speaker: Twin.
sp.p: Was he your favourite, Madam?—Sir, you are very obliging.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My Lord, if it were poſſible for your Lordſhip to call to your remembrance ſuch a trifle—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear Sir Luke—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Egad, I believe I do call to my remembrance— [Gravely conſidering.]—Not, I aſſure you, Sir, that I perceive any great reſemblance—or, if it was ſo—I dare ſay it is merely in the dreſs——which I muſt own ſtrikes me as moſt ridiculous—very ridiculous indeed.——

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I beg pardon, if I have ſaid any thing that——Lady Tremor, what did I ſay?——make my apology, if I have ſaid any thing improper—you know my unhappy failing.

sp.speaker: Lady. [to Twineall.]
sp.p: Sir, his Lordſhip has made a miſtake in the word "ridiculous," which I am ſure he did not mean to ſay—but he is apt to make uſe of one word for another—his Lordſhip has been ſo long out of England, that he may be ſaid in ſome meaſure to have forgotten his native language.

div.stage: [His Lordſhip all this time appears conſequentially abſent.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
And you have perfectly explained, Madam—indeed I ought to have been convinced,
without your explanation, that if his Lordſhip made uſe of the word ridiculous (even intentionally) that the word had now changed its former ſenſe, and was become a mode to expreſs ſatisfaction—or his Lordſhip wou'd not have made uſe of it in the very forcible manner he did, to a perfect ſtranger.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What, Mr. Twineall, have you new modes, new faſhions for words too in England, as well as for dreſſes?—and are you equally extravagant in their adoption?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I never heard, Sir Luke, but that the faſhion of words varied, as well as the faſhion of every thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But what is moſt extraordinary—we have now a faſhion in England, of ſpeaking without any words at all.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how is that?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Ay, do, Mr. Twineall, teach my wife, and I ſhall be very much obliged to you—it will be a great accompliſhment. Even you, my Lord, ought to be attentive to this faſhion.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, Madam, for inſtance, when a gentleman is aſked a queſtion which is either troubleſome or improper to anſwer, you don't ſay you won't anſwer it, even though you ſpeak to an inferior——but you ſay——"really it appears to me e-e-e-e-e— [mutters and ſhrugs]—that is—mo-mo-mo-mo-mo— [mutters]—if you ſee the thing—for my part——te-te-te-te——and that's all I can tell about it at perſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And you have told nothing!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Nothing upon earth.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But mayn't one gueſs what you mean?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, yes—perfectly at liberty to gueſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, I'll be ſhot if I could gueſs.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
And again—when an impertinent pedant
aſks you a queſtion that you know nothing about, and it may not be convenient to ſay ſo—you anſwer boldly, "why really, Sir, my opinion is, that the Greek poet—he-he-he-he— [mutters]—we-we-we-we—you ſee—if his idea was—and if the Latin tranſlator—mis-mis-mis-mis— [ſhrugs]——that I ſhou'd think—in my humble opinion—but the Doctor may know better than I."——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: The Doctor muſt know very little elſe.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Or in caſe of a duel, where one does not care to ſay who was right, or who was wrong—you anſwer—"This, Sir, is the ſtate of the matter—Mr. F—came firſt—te-te-te-te—on that—be-be-be-be—if the other—in ſhort— [whiſpers]—whis-whis-whis-whis"—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: There, now you have it—there 'tis—but don't ſay a word about it—or, if you do—don't ſay it come from me."—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, you have not told a word of the ſtory!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But that your auditor muſt not ſay to you—that's not the faſhion—he never tells you that——he may ſay—"You have not made yourſelf perfectly clear;"—or he may ſay—" He muſt have the matter more particularly pointed out ſomewhere elſe;"—but that is all the auditor can ſay with good breeding.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A very pretty method indeed to ſatisfy one's curioſity!

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Haſwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: This is a countryman of ours, Mr. Twineall, and a very good man I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Mr. Haſwell, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Sir Luke, I am glad to ſee you.——Lady Tremor, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, Mr. Haſwell, I am extremely glad you are come—here is a young adventurer juſt arrived from England, who has been giving us ſuch a ſtrange account of all that's going on there.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Sir, you are welcome to India. [Sir Luke whiſpers Haſwell. Indeed!—his ſon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do, Mr. Haſwell, talk to him—he can give you great information.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I am glad of it—I ſhall then hear many things I am impatient to become acquainted with. [Goes up to Twineall.] Mr. Twineall, I have the honour of knowing his Lordſhip, your father, extremely well—he holds his ſeat in Parliament ſtill, I preſume?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: He does, Sir.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: And your uncle, Sir Charles?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Both, Sir—both in Parliament ſtill.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, has any act in behalf of the poor clergy taken place yet?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: In behalf of the poor clergy, Sir?—I'll tell you—l'll tell you, Sir.——As to that act—concerning— [ſhrugs and mutters]—em-em-em-em—the Committee—em-em—ways and means—hee-hee—I aſſure you, Sir—te-te-te— [Sir Luke, Lady, and Lord Flint laugh. My father and my uncle both think ſo, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Think how, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Nay, that's not good breeding—you muſt aſk no more queſtions.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Becauſe—we-we-we-we— [mimicks]—he knows nothing about it.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What, Sir—not know?

sp.speaker: Twi
sp.p: Yes, Sir, perfectly acquainted with every thing that paſſes in the houſe—but I aſſure you, that when they come to be reported——but, Sir Luke, now permit me, in my turn, to make a few inquiries concerning the ſtate of this country.

div.stage: [Sir Luke ſtarts, and fixes his eyes ſuſpiciouſly on Lord Flint.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why, one does not like to ſpeak much about the country one lives in—but, Mr. Haſwell, you have been viſiting our encampments; you may tell us what is going on there.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Haſwell, is it true that the Sultan cut off the head of one of his wives the other day becauſe ſhe ſaid "I won't?"

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Do, my dear, be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I won't.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, that the Sultan had you inſtead of me!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And with my head off, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my dear; in that ſtate, I ſhou'd have no objection to you myſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady. [Aſide to Sir Luke.]
sp.p: Now, I'll frighten you ten times more.—But, Mr. Haſwell, I am told there are many perſons ſuſpected of diſaffection to the preſent Sultan, who have been lately, by his orders, arreſted, and ſold to ſlavery, notwithſtanding there was no proof againſt them produced.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Proof!——in a State ſuch as this, the charge is quite ſufficient.

speaker.hi:
Sir Luke. [In apparent agonies, wiſhing to turn
the diſcourſe.]

sp.p: Well, my Lord, and how does your Lordſhip find yourſelf this afternoon?—this morning, I mean—Bleſs my ſoul! why I begin to be as forgetful as your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How I pity the poor creatures!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Aſide to Lady.]
sp.p: Take care what you ſay before that tool of ſtate—look at him, and tremble for your head.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Look at him, and tremble for yours—and ſo, Mr. Haſwell, all this is true?—and ſome people, of conſequence too, I am told, dragged from their homes, and ſent to ſlavery merely on ſuſpicion?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Yet, leſs do I pity thoſe, than ſome, whom priſons and dungeons crammed before, are yet prepared to receive.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Mr. Haſwell, ſuch is the Sultan's pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip take a turn in the garden? it looks from this door very pleaſant;—does not it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But pray, Mr. Haſwell, has not the Sultan ſent for you to attend at his palace this morning?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: He has, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There! I heard he had, but Sir Luke ſaid not.—I am told he thinks himſelf under the greateſt obligations to you.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: The report has flattered me—but if his highneſs ſhou'd think himſelf under obligations, I can readily point a way, by which he may acquit himſelf of them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In the mean time, I am ſure, you feel for thoſe poor ſufferers.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [With ſtifled emotion.]
sp.p:
Sir Luke, good morning to you—I call'd upon ſome trifling buſineſs, but I have out-ſtaid my time, and therefore
fore I'll call again in a couple of hours—Lady Tremor, good morning—my Lord—Mr. Twine-all—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Sir Luke, your garden does look ſo divinely beautiful—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Come, my Lord, will you take a turn in it? Come Mr. Twineall—come my dear— [taking ber hand.] I can't think what buſineſs Mr. Haſwell has to ſpeak to me upon—for my part, I am quite a plain man—and buſy myſelf about no one's affairs, except my own—but I dare ſay your Lordſhip has forgot all we have been talking about.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: If you permit me, Sir Luke, I'll hand the Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, if you pleaſe—come, Mr. Twineall, and I'll conduct you.

div.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Luke Tremor's.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: MY dear friend, after ſo long a ſeparation, how gland I am to meet you!—but how deviliſh unlucky that you ſhou'd, on the very day of my arrival, be going to ſet ſail for another part of the world! yet before you go, I muſt beg a favour of you—you know Sir Luke and his family perfectly well, I dare ſay?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I think ſo—I have been in his houſe near ſix years.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: The very perſon on earth I wanted!—Sir Luke has power here, I ſuppoſe?—a word from him might do a man ſome ſervice perhaps?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Why, yes; I don't know a man that has more influence at a certain place.

sp.speaker: Twin.
sp.p: And her Ladyſhip ſeems a very clever gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And I have a notion they think me very clever.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: I dare ſay they do.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Yes—but I mean very clever.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: No doubt!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
But, my dear friend, you muſt help me to make them think better of me ſtill—and when
my fortune is made, I'll make yours—for when I once become acquainted with people's diſpoſitions, their little weakneſſes, foibles and faults, I can wind, twiſt, twine, and get into the corner of every one's heart, and lie ſo ſnug, they can't know I'm there, till they want to pull me out, and find 'tis impoſſible.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Excellent talent!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Is not it? and now, my dear friend, do you inform me of the ſecret diſpoſitions, and propenſities of every one in this family, and of all their connections.—What Lady values herſelf upon one qualification, and what Lady upon another?—What Gentleman will like to be told of his accompliſhments? or his daughter's?—or of his horſes? or of his dogs?—now, my dear Ned, acquaint me with all this—and within a fortnight I will become the moſt neceſſary raſcal——not a creature ſhall know how to exiſt without me.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Why ſuch a man as you ought to have made your fortune in England.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No—my father, and my three uncles monopolized all the great men themſelves; and wou'd never introduce me where I was likely to become their rival—This—this is the very ſpot for me to diſplay my genius—But then I muſt penetrate the people firſt—and you will kindly ſave me that trouble.—Come, give me all their characters—all ſhort, all I am to praiſe—and all I am to avoid praiſing,—in order to endear myſelf to them. [Takes out tablets.] Come—begin with Sir Luke.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Sir Luke—values himſelf more upon perſonal bravery, than upon any thing elſe.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Thank you, my dear friend—thank you. [Writes] Was he ever in the army?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Oh yes—beſieged a capital fortreſs, a few years ago—and now, the very name of a battle or a great general tickles his vanity, and he takes all the praiſes you can laviſh upon the ſubject as compliments to himſelf.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you a thouſand times— [Writes.] I'll mention a battle very ſoon.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Not directly.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, no—let me alone for time and place—go on, my friend—go on—her Ladyſhip—

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Deſcended from the ancient kings of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: You don't ſay ſo!

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: And though ſhe is ſo nicely ſcrupulous as never to mention the word genealogy, yet I have ſeen her agitation ſo great, when the advantages of high birth have been extoll'd, ſhe could ſcarcely withhold her ſentiments of triumph; which in order to diſguiſe, ſhe has aſſumed a diſdain for all "vain titles—empty ſounds—and idle pomp."

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Thank you—thank you—this is a moſt excellent trait of the Lady's— [Writes.] "Pedigree of the kings of Scotland?" O, I have her at once.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Yet do it nicely—oblique touches, rather than open explanations.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Let me alone for that.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: She has, I know, in her poſſeſſion—but I dare ſay ſhe wou'd not ſhow it you, nay, on the contrary, would even affect to be highly offended, if you were to mention it—and yet it certainly would flatter her, to know you were acquainted with her having it.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: What—what—what is it?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
A large old-faſhioned wig—which Malcolm
the third or fourth, her great anceſtor, wore when he was crowned at Scone, in the year——

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I'll mention it.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Take care.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, let me alone for the manner

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: She'll pretend to be angry.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: That I am prepared for.—Pray who is my Lord Flint?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: A deep man—and a great favourite at court.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Indeed!—how am I to pleaſe him?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: By inſinuations againſt the preſent Sultan.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: With all his pretended attachment, his heart——

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Are you ſure of it?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Sure:—he blinds Sir Luke, (who by the bye is no great politician) but I know his Lordſhip—and if he thought he was ſure of his ground—(and he thinks he ſhall be ſure of it ſoon)—then—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I'll inſinuate myſelf and join his party—but, in the mean time, preſerve good terms with Sir Luke, in caſe any thing ſhou'd fall in my way there.—Who is Mr. Haſwell?

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: He pretends to be a man of principle and ſentiment—flatter him on that.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: The eaſieft thing in the world—no people like flattery better than ſuch as he.—They will bear even to hear their vices praiſed.—I will myſelf undertake to praiſe the vices of a man of ſentiment till he ſhall think them ſo many virtues.—You have mentioned no Ladies, but the Lady of the houſe yet.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
There is no other Lady, except a pretty girl who came over from England, about two years ago, for a huſband, and not ſucceeding in another
part of the country, is now recommended to this houſe—and has been here three or four months.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Let me alone, to pleaſe her.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Let me alone, to pleaſe her.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: Yes—I believe you are ſkilled.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: For the art of flattery, no one more.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p: But damn it—it is not a liberal art.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: It is a great ſcience, notwithſtanding—and ſtudied, at preſent, by all the connoiſſeurs.—Zounds! I have ſtaid a long time—I can't attend to any more characters at preſent—Sir Luke and his Lady will think me inattentive, if I don't join them—Shall I ſee you again?—if not—I wiſh you a pleaſant voyage—I'll make the moſt of what you have told me—you'll hear I'm a great man—God bleſs you!—good bye!—you'll hear I'm a great man.

sp.speaker: Mean.
sp.p:
And, if I am not miſtaken, I ſhall hear you are turned out of the houſe before to-morrow morning. O, Twineall! exactly the reverſe of every character have you now before you—the greateſt misfortune in the • ife of Sir Luke has been, flying from his army in the midſt of an engagement, and a moſt humiliating degradation in conſequence, which makes him ſo feelingly alive on the ſubject of a battle, that nothing but his want of courage can ſecure my friend Twineall's life for venturing to name the ſubject—then Lord Flint, firmly attached to the intereſt of the Sultan, will be all on fire, when he hears of open diſaffection—but moſt of all her Ladyſhip! whoſe father was a grocer, and uncle, a noted advertiſing "Periwig-maker on a new conſtruction." She will run mad to hear of births, titles, and long pedigrees.—Poor Twineall! little doſt thou think what is prepared for thee.—There is Mr. Haſwell too—but to him have I ſent you to be reclaimed—to him,—who, free from faults, or even foibles,
of his own, has yet more potently the bleſſing given, of tenderneſs for ours.

div.head: SCENE II. The inſide of a Priſon.
div.stage: Several Priſoners diſperſed in different ſituations.
Enter Keeper and Haſwell with lights.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This way, Sir—the priſons this way are more extenſive ſtill—you ſeem to feel for theſe unthinking men—but they are a ſet of unruly people, whom no ſeverity can make ſuch as they ought to be.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: And wou'd not gentleneſs, or mercy, do you think, reclaim them?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That I can't ſay—we never try thoſe means in this part of the world—that man yonder, ſuſpected of diſaffection, is ſentenced to be here for life, unleſs his friends can lay down a large ſum by way of penalty, which he finds they cannot do, and he is turned melancholy.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [After a pauſe.]
sp.p: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: He has been try'd for heading an inſurrection, and acquitted.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What keeps him here?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Fees due to the Court—a debt contracted while he proved his innocence.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Lead on, my friend—let us go to ſome other part.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: In this ward, we are going to, are the priſoners, who by ſome ſmall reſerve—ſome little ſecreted ſtock when they arrived—or by the bounty of ſome friend who viſit them——or ſuch-like fortunate circumſtance, are in a leſs diſmal place.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Lead on.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: But ſtop—put on this cloak, for, before we arrive at the place I mention, we muſt paſs a damp vault, which to thoſe who are not uſed to it— [Haſwell puts on the cloak]—or will you poſtpone your viſit?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: No—go on.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Alas! who wou'd ſuppoſe you had been uſed to ſee ſuch places!—you look concerned—vext to ſee the people ſuffer—I wonder you ſhou'd come, when you ſeem to think ſo much about them.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Oh! that, that is the very reaſon.

div.stage: [Zedan, a tawny Indian Priſoner, follows them, ſtealing out, as if intent on ſomething.]
Two Priſoners walk ſlowly down the Stage.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Priſ.
sp.p: Who is this man?

sp.speaker: 2d Priſ.
sp.p: From Britain—I have ſeen him once before.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Priſ.
sp.p: He looks pale—he has no heart.

sp.speaker: 2d Priſ.
sp.p: I believe, a pretty large one.

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Brother, a word with you. [To the Iſt Priſoner, the other retires] as the ſtranger and our keeper paſſed by the paſſage, a noxious vapour put out the light, and as they groped along I purloined this from the ſtranger— [Shews a pocket-book]ſee it contains two notes will pay our ranſom.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Priſ.
sp.p: A treaſure—our certain ranſom!

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Liberty! our wives, our children, and our friends, will theſe papers purchaſe.

sp.speaker: 1ſt Priſ.
sp.p: What a bribe! our keeper may rejoice too.

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: And then the pleaſure it will be to hear the ſtranger fret, and complain for his loſs!—O, how my heart loves to ſee forrow!—Miſery ſuch as I have known, on men who ſpurn me—who treat me as if (in my own Iſland) I had no friends that loved me—no ſervants that paid me honour—no children that revered me—who forget I am a huſband—a father—nay, a man.—

sp.speaker: 1ſt Priſ.
sp.p: Conceal your thoughts—conceal your treature too—or the Briton's complaint—

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Will be in vain—our keeper will conclude the bribe muſt come to him, at laft—and therefore make no great ſearch for it—here, in the corner of my belt [Puts up the pocket-book] twill be ſecure—Come this way, and let us indulge our pleaſant proſpect.

div.head: SCENE III. Another part of the Priſon.
div.stage: A kind of ſopha with an old man ſleeping upon it—Elvirus ſitting attentively by him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: That young man, you ſee there, watching his aged father as he ſleeps, by the help of fees gains his admiſſion—and he never quits the place, except to go and purchaſe cordials for the old man, who, (though healthy and ſtrong when he firſt became a priſoner) is now become ill and languid.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Are they from Europe?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: No—but deſcended from Europeans—ſee how the youth holds his father's hand!—I have ſometimes caught him bathing it with tears.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I'll ſpeak to the young man.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p:
He will ſpeak as ſoon as he ſees me—he has ſent a petition to the Sultan about his father,
and never fails to inquire if a reply is come.

sp.speaker: Elv. [To Haſwell]
sp.p: Sir, do you come from the Court? has the Sultan received my humble ſupplication? Can you tell?—ſoftly—let not my father hear you ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I come but as a ſtranger, to ſee the priſoh.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No anſwer yet, keeper?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: No—I told you it was in vain to write—they never read petitions ſent from priſons—their hearts are hardened to ſuch worn-out tales of ſorrow.
sp.stage: [Elvirus turns towards his Father and weeps.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Pardon me, Sir—but what is the requeſt you are thus denied?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Behold my father! but three months has he been confined here; and yet—unleſs he breathes a purer air—O, if you have influence at Court, Sir, pray repreſent what paſſes in this dreary priſon—what paſſes in my heart.——My ſupplication is to remain a priſoner here, while my father, releaſed, ſhall be permitted to retire to humble life; and never more take arms in a cauſe the Sultan may ſuſpect—which engagement broken, my life ſhall be the forfeit.—Or if the Sultan wou'd allow me to ſerve him as a ſoldier.—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You would fight againſt the party your father fought for?

sp.speaker: Elv. [Starting.]
sp.p: No—but in the foreſts—or on the deſert ſands—amongſt thoſe ſlaves who are ſent to battle with the wild Indians—there I wou'd go—and earn the boon I aſk——or in the mines—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Give me your name—I will, at leaſt, preſent your ſuit—and, perhaps—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir! do you think it is likely? Joyful hearing!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p:
Nay, be not too haſty in your hopes—I
cannot anſwer for my ſucceſs [Repeats] Your father humbly implores to be releaſed from priſon—and, in his ſtead, you take his chains—or, for the Sultan's ſervice, fight as a ſlave, or dig in his mines?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Exactly, Sir—that is the petition—I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You don't know, young man, what it is to dig in mines—or fight againſt foes, who make their priſoners die by unheard-of tortures.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: You do not know, Sir, what it is—to ſee a parent ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [Writing]
sp.p: Your name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Elvirus Caſimir.—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Your father's?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The ſame—one who followed agriculture in the fields of Symria—but, induced by the call of freedom—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: How? have a care.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No—his ſon, by the call of nature, ſupplicates his freedom.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The rebel, you find, breaks out.

sp.speaker: Elv. [Aſide to the Keeper.]
sp.p: Silence—ſilence! he forgives it—don't remind him of it—don't undo my hopes.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I will ſerve you if I can.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And I will merit it—indeed I will—you ſhall not complain of me—I will be—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Retire—I truſt you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yonder cell contains a female priſoner.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: A female priſoner!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Without a friend or comforter, ſhe has exiſted there theſe many years—nearly fifteen.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Is it poſſible!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Wou'd you wiſh to ſee her?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: If it won't give her pain.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: At leaſt, ſhe'll not reſent it—for ſhe ſeldom complains, except in moans to herſelf— [Goes to the cell.] Lady, here is one come to viſt all the priſoners—pleaſe to appear before him.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I thank you—you ſpeak with reverence and reſpect to her.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: She has been of ſome note, though now ſo totally unfriended—at leaſt, we think ſhe has, from her gentle manners; and our governor is in the daily expectation of ſome liberal ranſom for her, which makes her impriſonment without a hope of releaſe, till that day arrives— [Going to the cell]—Lend me your hand—you are weak.
sp.stage: [He leads her from the cell—ſhe appears faint—and as if the light affected her eyes—Haſwell pulls off his hat, and, after a pauſe—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I fear you are not in health, Lady?

div.stage: [She looks at him ſolemnly for ſome time.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Speak—Madam, ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: No—not very well.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Where are your friends? When do you expect your ranſom?

sp.speaker: Priſ. [Shaking her head.]
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: She perſiſts to ſay ſo; thinking by that declaration, we ſhall releaſe her without a ranſom.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Is that your motive?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I know no motive for a falſehood.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I was to blame—pardon me.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Your anſwers are ſomewhat prouder than uſual.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: They are.— [To Haſwell] Forgive me—I am mild with all of theſe—but from a countenance like yours—I could not bear reproach.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You flatter me.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Alas! Sir, and what have I to hope from ſuch a meaneſs?—You do not come to ranſom me.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Perhaps I do.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Oh! do not ſay ſo—unleſs—unleſs—I am not to be deceived—pardon in your turn this ſuſpicion—but when I have ſo much to hope for—when the ſun, the air, fields, woods, and all that wonderous world, wherein I have been ſo happy, is in proſpect; forgive me, if the vaſt hope makes me fear.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Unleſs your ranſom is fixed at ſomething beyond my power to give, I will releaſe you.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Releaſe me! Benevolent!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: How ſhall I mark you down in my petition? [Takes out his book.] what name?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: 'Tis almoſt blotted from my memory.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: It is of little note—a female priſoner, taken with the rebel party, and in theſe cells confined for fiſteen years.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Daring which time I have demeaned myſelf with all humility to my governors—neither have I diſtracted my fellow priſoners with a complaint that might recall to their memory their own unhappy fate—I have been obedient, patient; and cheriſhed hope to chear me with vain dreams, while deſpair poſſeſs'd my reaſon.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Retire—I will preſent the picture you have given.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Succeed too—or, never let me ſee you more—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You never ſhall.

sp.speaker: Priſ. [Returrs]
sp.p: Or, if you ſhou'd miſcarry in your views [for who forms plans that do not ſometimes ſail?] I will not reproach you even to myſelf——no—nor will I ſuffer much from the diſappointment—merely that you may not have, what I ſuffer, to account for.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Excellent mind!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: In this cell—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: No—take me away—I have enough to do—I dare not ſee more at preſent.—

div.head: SCENE IV. The former Priſon Scene.

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: They are coming—I'll ſtand here in his ſight, that, ſhou'd he miſs what I have taken, he'll not ſuſpect me, but ſuppoſe it is one who has hid himſelf.

sp.speaker: Keep. [To Zedan]
sp.p: What makes you here?—ſtill moping by yourſelf, and lamenting for your family?— [To Haſwell] that man, the moſt ferocious I ever met with—laments, ſometimes even with tears, the ſeparation from his wife and children.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [Going to him]
sp.p: I am ſorry for you, friend; [Zedan looks ſullen and moroſe.] I pity you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes—he had a pleaſant hamlet on the neighbouring iſland—plenty of fruits—clear ſprings—and wholeſome roots—and now complains bitterly of his repaſts—ſour rice, and muddy water.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Poor man! bear your ſorrows nobly—and as we are alone—no miſerable eye to grudge the favour— [Looking round] take this trifle— [Gives money] it will at leaſt make your meals better for a few ſhort weeks—till Heaven may pleaſe to favour you with a leſs ſharp remembrance of the happineſs you have loſt—Farewell.

div.stage: [Zedan catches hold of him. and taking the pocket-book from his belt, puts it into Haſwell's hand.]

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What's this?

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: I meant to gain my liberty with it—but I will not vex you.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: How came you by it?

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Stole it—and wou'd have ſtabb'd you too, had you been alone—but I am glad I did not—Oh! I am glad I did not.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You like me then?

sp.speaker: Zed. [Shakes his head and holds his heart.]
sp.p: 'Tis ſomething that I never felt before—it makes me like not only you, but all the world beſides—the love of my family was confined to them alone; but this makes me feel I could love even my enemies.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Oh, nature! grateful! mild! gentle! and forgiving!—worſt of tyrants they who, by hard uſage, drive you to be cruel!

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: The lights are ready, Sir, through the dark paſſage— [To Zedan.] Go to your fellows.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [To Zedan.]
sp.p: Farewell—we will meet again.

div.stage: [Zedan exit on one ſide, Haſwell and Keeper exeunt on the other.

div.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Luke Tremor's.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: WHY, then Aurelia, (though I never mention'd it to my Lady Tremor) my friend wrote me word, he had reaſon to ſuppoſe your affections were improperly fixed upon a young gentleman in that neighbourhood; and this was his reaſon for wiſhing you to leave that place to come hither—and this continual dejection convinces me my friend was not miſtaken—anſwer me—can you ſay he was?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, then, Sir Luke, candidly to confeſs—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Nay, no tears—why in tears? for a huſband? be comforted—we'll get you one ere long, I warrant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear, Sir Luke, how can you imagine I am in tears becauſe I have not a huſband, while you ſee Lady Tremor every day in tears for the very oppoſite cauſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No matter—women like a huſband through pride—and I have known a woman marry from that very motive, even a man ſhe has been aſhamed of.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why, then I dare ſay, poor Lady Tremor married from pride.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes;—and I'll let her know pride is painful.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But, Sir, her Ladyſhip's philoſophy—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: She has no philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Where is his Lordſhip? What have you done with him?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He's ſpeaking a word to Mr. Meanright about his paſſport to England.—Did you mean me, Sir Luke, that had no philoſophy? I proteſt, I have a great deal.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: When? where did you ſhew it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, when the ſervant at my Lady Griſſei's threw a whole urn of boiling water upon your legs, did I give any proofs of female weakneſs? did I faint, ſcream, or even ſhed a tear?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—no—very true—and while I lay ſprawling on the carnet, I could ſee you fanning and holding the ſmelling bottle to the Lady of the houſe, begging her not to make herſelf uneaſy, for that the accident was of no manner of conſequence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear Sir, don't be angry;—I am ſure her Ladyſhip ſpoke as ſhe thought.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe ſhe did, Miſs.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I mean—ſhe thought the accident might be eaſily got the better of—She thought you might be eaſily recovered.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, indeed, I did not—but I thought Sir Luke had frequently charged me with the want of patience; and that moment, the very thing in the world I cou'd have wiſhed, happened—on purpoſe to give me an opportunity to prove his accuſation falſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
Very well, Madam—but did not the
whole company cry ſhame on your behaviour? did not they ſay, it was not the conduct of a wife?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Only our particular acquaintance cou'd ſay ſo—for the reſt of the company, I am ſure, did not take me to be your wife—thank Heaven, our appearances never betray that ſecret—do you think we look like the ſame fleſh and blood?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: That day, in particular, we did not—for I remember you had been no leſs than three hours at your toilet.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: And, indeed, Sir Luke, if you were to uſe milk of roſes, and ſeveral other little things of that kind, you can't think how much more like a fine gentleman you wou'd look.—Such things as thoſe make, almoſt, all the difference there is between you and ſuch a gentleman as Mr. Twineall.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No, pardon me, Madam—a face like mine may uſe thoſe things—but in Sir Luke's, they wou'd entirely deſtroy that fine martial appearance— [Sir Luke looks confounded.] which women as well as men admire—for, as valour is the firſt ornament of our ſex—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What are you ſaying, Mr. Twineall? [Aſide.] I'll keep him on this ſubject if I can.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I was going to obſerve, Madam—that the reputation of a General—which puts me in mind, Sir Luke, of an account I read of a battle—
sp.stage: [He croſſes over to Sir Luke, who turns up the Stage in the utmoſt confuſion, and ſteals out of the room.]

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Well, Sir—go on—go on—you were going to introduce—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: A battle, Madam—but, Sir Luke is gone!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Never mind that, Sir—he generally runs away on theſe occaſions.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Coming back.]
sp.p: What were you ſaying, Aurelia, about a huſband?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She did not ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: To be ſure, Ladies in India do get huſbands very quick.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Not always—I am told, Sir Luke—Women of family, [fixing his eyes ſtedfaſtly on Lady Tremor.] indeed, may ſoon enter into the matrimonial ſtate—but the rich men in India, we are told in England, are grown lately very particular with whom they marry, and there is not a man of any repute that will now look upon a woman as a wife, unleſs ſhe is deſcended from a good family.
sp.stage: [Looking at Lady Tremor, who walks up the Stage and ſteals off, juſt as Sir Luke had done before.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I am very ſorry—very ſorry to ſay, Mr. Twineall, that has not been always the caſe.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Then I am very ſorry too, Sir Luke; for it is as much impoſſible that a woman, who is not born of a good family, can be—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: That is juſt what I ſay—they cannot be—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: It does not ſignify telling, my dear,—you have proved it.

sp.speaker: Lady. [To Twineall.]
sp.p: Sir, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O! O! my dear Madam, 'tis all in vain—there is no ſuch thing—it can't be—there is no pleading againſt conviction—a perſon of low birth muſt, in every particular, be a terrible creature.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Going to her.]
sp.p: A terrible creature! a terrible creature!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here comes my Lord Flint—I'll appeal to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Going to him.]
sp.p: My Lord, I was ſaying, as proof that our great Sultan, who now fills this throne, is no impoſtor, (as the rebel party wou'd inſinuate) no low born man, but of the Royal Stock; his conduct palpably evinces—for, had he not been nobly born, we ſhou'd have beheld the Plebeian burſting forth upon all occaſions [Looking at Lady Tremor] and then, Heaven help all thoſe who had had any dealings with him!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Provoking!

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir Luke, is there a doubt of the Emperor's birth and title? he is the real Sultan, depend upon it—it ſurpriſes me to hear you talk with the ſmalleſt uncertainty.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, Sir Luke, I wonder at it too, [Aſide to Lord Flint.] and yet, damn me, my Lord, if I have not my doubts.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I, my Lord? far be it from me! I was only ſaying what other people ſaid; for my part I never harboured a doubt of the kind.— [Aſide.] My head begins to nod, only for that word—pray Heaven, I may die with it on!—I ſhou'd not like to loſe my head—nor ſhou'd I like to die by a bullet—nor by a ſmall ſword—and a cannon ball wou'd be as diſagreeable, as any thing, I know—it is very odd—but I never yet could make up my mind, in what manner I ſhou'd. like to go out of the world.
sp.stage: [During this ſpeech. Twineall is paying court to Lord Flint; they come forward and Sir Luke retires.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Your temerity aſtoniſhes me!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
I muſt own, my Lord, I feel ſomewhat aukward in ſaying it to your Lordſhip—but my own heart—my own conſcience—my own ſentiments—they are my own—and they are dear to
me.—And ſo it is—the Sultan does not appear to be [With ſignificance.] that great man ſome people think him.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir, you aſtoniſh me—pray what is your name? I have forgotten it.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Twineall, my Lord—the honourable Henry Twineall—your Lordſhip does me great honour to aſk—arrived this morning from England, as your Lordſhip may remember—in the ſhip Mercury, my Lord—and all the officers on board ſpeaking with the higheſt admiration and warmeſt terms of your Lordſhip's official character.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why, then, Mr. Twineall, I am very ſorry—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And ſo am I, my Lord, that your ſentiments and mine ſhou'd ſo far diſagree, as I know they do.—I am not unacquainted with your firm adherence to the Emperor—but I am unuſed to diſguiſe my thoughts—I cou'd not, if I wou'd—I have no little views—no ſiniſter motives—no plots—no intrigues—no ſchemes of preferment,—and I verily believe that if a large ſcymitar was now directed at my head—or a large penſion directed to my pocket—(in the firſt caſe at leaſt) I ſhou'd ſpeak my mind.

sp.speaker: Lord. [Aſide.]
sp.p: A dangerous young man this! and I may make ſomething of the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Twi. [Aſide.]
sp.p: It tickles him to the ſoul, I find.—My Lord, now I begin to be warm on the ſubject, I feel myſelf quite agitated—and, from the intelligence which I have heard, even when I was in England,—there is every reaſon to ſuppoſe——exm—exm—exm——

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What, Sir? what?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: You underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No, Sir—explain.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, then, there is every reaſon to ſuppoſe—ſome people are not what they ſhou'd be—pardon my thoughts, if they are wrong.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I do pardon your thoughts, with all my heart—but your words, young man, muſt be anſwer'd for [Aſide.] Lady Tremor, good morning.

sp.speaker: Twi. [Aſide.]
sp.p: He is going to ruminate on my ſentiments, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Shall we have your Lordſhip's company towards the evening? Mr. Haſwell will be here; if your Lordſhip has no objection?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: How do you know Mr. Haſwell will be here?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Becauſe he has juſt called, in his way to the Palace, and ſaid ſo—and he has been telling us ſome very intereſting ſtories too.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Of his moring viſits, I ſuppoſe—I heard Meanright ſay he ſaw him very buſy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke and I dine out, my Lord; but we ſhall return early in the evening.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I will be here, without fail.—Sir Luke, aword with you if you pleaſe— [They come forward.] Mr. Twineall has taken ſome very improper liberties with the Sultan's name, and I muſt inſiſt on making him anſwer for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My Lord, you are extremely welcome [Trembling.] to do whatever your Lordſhip pleaſes with any one belonging to me, or to my houſe—but I hope your Lordſhip will pay ſome regard to the maſter of it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: O! great regard to the maſter—and to the miſtreſs alſo.—But for that gentleman—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Do what your Lordſhip pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I will—and I will make him—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip does not forget it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I ſhan't forget it, Sir Luke—I have a very good memory, when I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I don't, in the leaſt, doubt it, my Lord—I never did doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And I can be very ſevere too, Sir Luke, when I pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I don't, in the leaſt, doubt it, my Lord—I never did doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You may depend upon ſeeing me here in the evening—and then you ſhall find I have not threatened more than I mean to perform—good morning!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Good morning, my Lord—I don't in the leaſt doubt it.

sp.speaker: Lady. [Coming, forward with Twineall.]
sp.p: For Heaven's ſake, Mr. Twineall, what has birth to do with—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: It has to do with every thing, Madam—even with beauty—and I wiſh I may ſuffer death, if a woman, with all the mental and perſonal accompliſhments of the fineſt creature in Europe, wou'd to me be of that value, [Snapping his finger.] if lowly born.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And I ſincerely wiſh every man who viſits me was of the ſame opinion.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: For ſhame, Mr. Twineall! perſons of mean birth ought not to be deſpiſed for what it was not in their power to prevent—and if it is a misfortune, you ſhou'd conſider them only as objects of pity.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And ſo I do pity them—and ſo I do—moſt ſincerely—poor creatures.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Aye, now he has mended it finely.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Mr. Twineall, let me tell you—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p:
My dear—Lady Tremor— [Taking her aſide.] let him alone—let him go on—there is ſomething preparing for him he little expects—ſo let the poor man ſay and do what he pleaſes, for the preſent—it won't laſt long—for he has offended
my Lord Flint, and, I dare ſay his Lordſhip will be able, upon ſome account or another, to get him impriſoned for life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Impriſoned! Why not take off his head at once?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, my dear—I am ſure I have no objection—and I dare ſay my Lord will have it done, to oblige you.—Egad, I muſt make friends with her to keep mine ſafe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you mean to take him out to dinner with us?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, if you approve of it—not elſe.

sp.speaker: Lady
sp.p: You are grown extremely polite.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, his Lordſhip has taught me how to be polite.—Mr. Twineall, Lady Tremor and I are going to prepare for our viſit, and I will ſend a ſervant to ſhew you to your apartment, in order to dreſs, for you will favour us with your company, I hope?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir Luke, I ſhall do myſelf the honour.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come this way, Aurelia, I can't bear to look at him.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Nor I to think of him.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
If I have not ſettled my buſineſs in this family, I am miſtaken—they ſeem to have but one mind about me.—Deviliſh clever fellow, egad!—I am the man to ſend into the world—ſuch a volatile, good-looking ſcoundrel too! No one ſuſpects me——to be ſure I am under ſome few obligations to my friend for letting me into the different characters of the family—and yet I don't know whether I am obliged to him or not—for if he had not made me acquainted with them—I ſhou'd ſoon have had the ſkill to find them out myſhelf.—No; I will not think myſhelf under any
obligation to him—it is deviliſh inconvenient for a gentleman to be under an obligation.

div.head: SCENE II. The Place. The Sultan diſcovered with guards and officers attending.
div.stage: Haſwell is conducted in by an officer.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Sir you are ſummoned to receive our thanks, for the troops reſtored to health by your kind preſcriptions.—Aſk a reward adequate to your ſervices.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Sultan—the reward I aſk, is to preſerve more of your people ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: How more? my ſubjects are in health—no contagion reigns amongſt them.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: The priſoner is your ſubject—there miſery—more contagious than diſeaſe, preys on the lives of hundreds—ſentenced but to confinement, their doom is death.—Immured in damp and dreary vaults, they daily periſh—and who can tell but that amongſt the many hapleſs ſufferers, there may be hearts, bent down with penitence to Heaven and you, for every ſlight offence—there may be ſome amongſt the wretched multitude, even innocent victims.—Let me ſeek them out—let me ſave them, and you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Amazement! retract your application—curb this weak pity; and receive our thanks.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Curb my pity?—and what can I receive in recompence for that ſoft bond, which links me to the wretched?—and while it ſooths their ſorrow repays me more, than all the gifts or homage of an empire.——But if repugnant to your plan of government—not in the name of pity—but of juſttice.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Juſtice!——

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: The juſtice which forbids all but the worſt of criminals to be denied that wholeſome air the very brute creation freely takes; at leaſt allow them that.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Conſider, Sir, for whom you plead—for men, (if not baſe culprits) yet ſo miſled, ſo depraved, they are offenſive to our ſtate, and deſerve none of its bleſſings.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: If not upon the undeſerving,—if not upon the hapleſs wanderer from the paths of rectitude,—where ſhall the ſun diffuſe his light, or the clouds diſtil their dew? Where ſhall ſpring breathe fragrance, or autumn pour its plenty?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Sir, your ſentiments, but much more your character, excite my curioſity. They tell me, in our camps, you viſited each ſick man's bed,—adminiſtered yourſelf the healing draught,—encouraged our ſavages with the hope of life, or pointed out their better hope in death.—The widow ſpeaks your charities—the orphan liſps your bounties—and the rough Indian melts in tears to bleſs you.—I wiſh to aſk why you have done all this?—What is it prompts you thus to befriend the wretched and forlorn?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: In vain for me to explain—the time it wou'd take to tell you why I act thus—

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Send it in writing then.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Nay, if you will read, I'll ſend a book, in which is already written why I act thus.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What book?—What is it called?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: "The Chriſtian Doctrine." [Haſwell bows here with the utmoſt reverence.] There you will find all I have done was but my duty.

sp.speaker: Sul. [To the Guards.]
sp.p: Retire, and leave me alone with the ſtranger.
sp.stage: [All retire except Haſwell and the Sultan. They come forward.]

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p:
Your words recall reflections that diſtract
me; nor can I bear the preſſure on my mind without confeſſing—I am a Chriſtian.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: A Chriſtian!—What makes you thus aſſume the apoſtate?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Miſery, and deſpair.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What made you a Chriſtian?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: My Arabella,—a lovely European, ſent hither in her youth, by her mercenary parents, to ſell herſelf to the prince of all theſe territories. But 'twas my happy lot, in humble life, to win her love, ſnatch her from his expecting arms, and bear her far away—where, in peaceful ſolitude we lived, till, in the heat of the rebellion againſt the late Sultan, I was forced from my happy home to bear a part.—I choſe the imputed rebels ſide, and fought for the young aſpirer.—An arrow, in the midſt of the engagement, pierced his heart; and his officers, alarmed at the terror this ſtroke of fate might cauſe amongſt their troops, urged me (as I bore his likeneſs) to counterfeit it farther, and ſhew myſelf to the ſoldiers as their king recovered. I yielded to their ſuit, becauſe it gave me ample power to avenge the loſs of my Arabella, who had been taken from her home by the mercileſs foe, and barbarouſly murdered.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Murdered!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I learnt ſo—and my fruitleſs ſearch to find her ſince has conſirmed the intelligence.—Frantic for her loſs, I joyfully embraced a ſcheme which promiſed vengeance on the enemy—it proſpered,—and I revenged my wrongs and her's, with ſuch unſparing juſtice on the foe, that even the men who made me what I was, trembled to reveal their impoſition; and they find it ſtill their intereſt to continue it.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Amazement!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Nay, they fill my priſons every day with wretches, that dare whiſper I am not the real Sultan, but a ſtranger. The ſecret, therefore, I myſelf ſafely relate in private: the danger is to him who ſpeaks it again; and, with this caution, I truſt, it is ſafe with you.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: It was, without that caution.—Now hear me.—Involved in deeds, in cruelties, which your better thoughts revolt at, the meaneſt wretch your camps or priſons hold, claims not half the compaſſion you have excited. Permit me, then, to be your comforter, as I have been theirs.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: In the moſt fatal ſymptoms I have undertaken the body's cure. The mind's diſeaſe, perhaps, I'm not leſs a ſtranger to—Oh! truſt the noble patient to my care.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: How will you begin?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Lead you to behold the wretched in their miſery, and then ſhew you yourſelf in their deliverer.—I have your promiſe for a boon—'tis this.—Give me the liberty of fix that I ſhall name, now in confinement, and be yourſelf a witneſs of their enlargement.—See joy lighted in the countenance where ſorrow ſtill has left its rough remains.—Behold the tear of rapture chaſe away that of anguiſh—hear the faultering voice, long uſed to lamentation, in broken accents, utter thanks and bleſſings.—Behold this ſcene, and if you find the medicine ineffectual, diſhonour your phyſician.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I will behold it.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p:
Come, then, to the governor's houſe this very night—into that council room ſo often perverted to the uſe of the torture; and there, unknown to them as their king, you ſhall be witneſs
me; nor can I bear the preſſure on my mind without confeſſing—I am a Chriſtian.

sp.p: A Chriſtian!—What makes you thus aſſume the apoſtate?

sp.p: Miſery, and deſpair.
