to all the grateful heart can dictate, and enjoy all that benevolence can taſte.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: I will meet you there.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: In the evening?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: At ten preciſely.—Guards, conduct the ſtranger from the palace.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Thus far advanced, what changes may not be hoped for?

div.head: SCENE I. An Apartment at Sir Luke's:

sp.speaker: Elvirus.
sp.p: OH my Aurelia! ſince the time I firſt ſaw you—ſince you left the pleaſant ſpot, where I firſt beheld you; what diſtreſs, what anguiſh have we known?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Your family?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yes—and that cauſed the ſilence which I hope you have lamented.—I could not wound you with the recital of our misfortunes—and now, only with the ſad idea that I ſhall never ſee you more, I am come to take my leave.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Is there a chance that we may never meet again?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: There is—and I hope it too—ſincerely hope and requeſt it—to ſee you again, wou'd be again to behold my father pining in miſery.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Explain— [A loud rapping at the door.] that is, Sir Luke, and Lady Tremor—what ſhall I ſay, ſhou'd they come hither? they ſuſpect I correſpond with ſome perſon in the country—who ſhall I ſay you are? upon what buſineſs can I ſay you are come?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p:
To avoid all ſuſpicion of my real ſituation, and to be ſure to gain admittance, I put on this habit, and told the ſervant, when I inquired for you, I was juſt arrived from England— [She ſtarts.] nay, it was but neceſſary I ſhould conceal who I
was in this ſuſpicious place, or I might plunge a whoſe family in the imputed guilt of mine.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Good Heaven!

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I feared, beſides, there was no other means; no likelihood to gain admiſſion—and what, what wou'd I not have ſacrificed, rather than left you for ever without a laſt farewell? think on theſe weighty cauſes, and pardon the deception.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But if they ſhould aſk me—

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Say, as I have done—my ſtay muſt be ſo ſhort, it is impoſſible they ſhou'd detect me—for I muſt be back—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No matter where—I muſt be back before the evening—and would almoſt wiſh never to ſee you more—I love you, Aurelia—O, how truly! and yet there is a love more dear, more ſacred ſtill.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You torture me with ſuſpenſe—Sir Luke is coming this way—what name ſhall I ſay, if he aſks me?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Glanmore—I announced that name to the servant.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You tremble.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: The impoſition hurts me—and I feel as if I dreaded a detection, though 'tis ſcarce poſſible—Sorrows have made a coward of me—even the ſervant, I thought, looked at me with ſuſpicion—and I was both confounded and enraged.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Go into this apartment; I'll follow you—there we may be ſafe—and do not hide the ſmalleſt circumſtance which I may have to apprehend.

sp.speaker: Sir Lake. [Without.]
sp.p:
Abominable! provokin •
▪ impertinent! not to be borne!

sp.speaker: Aur. [Liſtening.]
sp.p: Thank Heaven, Sir Luke is ſo perplexed with ſome affairs of his own, he may not think of mine.—

div.stage: Enter Sir Luke, followed by Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I am out of all patience—and all temper—did you ever hear of ſuch a compleat impertinent coxcomb? Talk, talk, talk, coutinually! and referring to me on all occaſions! Such a man was a brave General—another a great Admiral, and then he muſt tell a long ſtory about a ſiege, and aſk me if it did not make my boſom glow!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: It had not that effect upon your face, for you were as white as aſhes.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke
sp.p: Aye, you did not ſee yourſelf, while he was talking of grandfathers and great grandfathers—if you had—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I was not white, I proteſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—but you were as red as ſcarlet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And you ought to have reſented the inſult, if you ſaw me affected by it—Oh! ſome men wou'd have given him ſuch a dreſſing—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes, my dear, if your uncle the friſſeur had been alive, he wou'd have given him a dreſſing, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir Luke, none of your impertinence; you know I can't nor won't bear it—neither will I wait for Lord Flint's reſentment on Mr. Twineall—No, I deſire you will tell him to quit this roof immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, my dear—no, no—you muſt excuſe me—I can't think of quarrelling with a gentleman in my own houſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Was it your own houſe to day at dinner when he inſulted us? and would quarrel then?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—that was a friend's houſe—and I make it a rule never to quarrel in my own houſe—a friend's houſe—in a tavern—or in the ſtreets.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Well, then, I would quarrel in my own
houſe—a friend's houſe—a tavern—or in the ſtreets—if any one offended me.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, my dear, I have no doubt of it—no doubt, in the leaſt.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But, at preſent, it ſhall be in my own houſe,—and I will tell the gentleman to quit it immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Very well, my dear—pray do.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe, however, I may tell him I have your authority to bid him go?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Tell him I have no authority—none in the world over you—but that you will do as you like.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can't tell him ſo—he won't believe it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why not? you often tell me ſo, and make me believe it too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Here the gentleman comes—go away for a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: With all my heart, my dear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll give him a few hints, that he muſt either change his mode of behaviour, or leave us.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: That's right—but don't be too warm—or if he ſhould be very impertinent, or inſolent—(i hear Aurelia's voice in the next room) call her, and I dare ſay ſhe'll come and take your part.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I poſitively could paſs a whole day upon that ſtair-caſe—thoſe reverend faces!—I preſume they are the portraits of ſome of your Ladyſhip's illuſtrious anceſtors.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir! Mr. Twineall—give me leave to tell you—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: The word illuſtrious, I find, diſpleaſes you—pardon me—I did not mean to make uſe of ſo forcible an epithet—I know the delicacy of ſentiment, which cannot bear the reflection that a few centuries only ſhou'd reduce from royalty, one, whoſe dignified deportment ſeems to have been formed for that reſplendent ſtation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: The man is certainly mad!——Mr. Twineall—

sp.speaker: Twi
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam—I own I am an enthuſiaſt on theſe occaſions—the dignity of blood—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have too much, I am ſure—do, have a little taken from you.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Gladly wou'd I loſe every drop that fills theſe plebeian veins, to be enobled by the ſmalleſt——

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, take up your abode in ſome other place.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Your behaviour, Sir—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: If my friend had not given me the hint, damn me if I ſhou'd not think her down right angry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can ſcarce contain my rage at being ſo laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Perhaps you may reſent it, Madam—but there is a favour—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A favour, Sir! is this a time to aſk a favour?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: To an admirer of antiquity, as I am.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Antiquity again!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I beg pardon——but——a wig, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A what?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: A wig.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Oh! oh! oh! [Choaking.] this is not to be borne—this is too much—ah! ah! [Sitting
down, and going into fits.] a direct, plain, palpable, and unequivocal attack upon my family—without evaſion or palliative.—I can't bear it any longer.—Oh! oh!—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul, what ſhall I do? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Without.]
sp.p: Maids! maids! go to your miſtreſs—that good-for-nothing fellow is doing her a miſchief.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear Madam, what is the matter?

div.stage: Enter Sir Luke, and ſtands cloſe to the ſcenes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: How do you do now, my dear?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir Luke—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, Sir, no apology—it does not ſignify—never mind it—I beg you won't put yourſelf to the trouble of an apology—it is of no kind of conſequence.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What do you mean, Sir Luke?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: To ſhew proper philoſophy, my dear, under the affliction I feel for your diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Lady, [To Aurelia.]
sp.p: Take Twineall out of the room.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Mr. Twineall, her Ladyſhip begs you'll leave the room, till ſhe is a little recovered.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Certainly
sp.stage: [Bows reſpectfully to ber Ladyſhip, and exit with Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: I thought what you wou'd get by quarrelling—fits—and tears.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
And you know, Sir Luke, if you had quarrelled, you wou'd have been in the ſame ſituation. [Riſing from her ſeat.] But, Sir Luke, my
dear, Sir Luke, ſhow yourſelf a man of courage but on this occaſion.—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: My dear, I wou'd do as much for you as I wou'd for my own life—but damn me if I think I could fight to ſave that.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Lady Tremor, did the ſervant ſay you were very well, or very ill?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, my Lord, that inſolent coxcomb, the honourable Mr. Twineall—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Oh, I am very glad you put me in mind of it—I dare ſay I ſhou'd have forgot it elſe, notwithſtanding I came on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forgot what?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: A little piece of paper here, [Pulling out a parchment.] but it will do a great deal—has he offended you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Beyond bearing.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I am glad of it, becauſe it gives double pleaſure to my vengeance—he is a diſaffected perſon, Madam—boldly told me he doubted the Sultan's right to the throne—I have informed againſt him, and his puniſhment is at my option—I may have him impriſoned; ſhot; ſent to the gallies; or his head cut off—but which does your Ladyſhip chuſe?—Which ever you pleaſe is at your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lady. [Riſing and curtſying.]
sp.p: O, they are all alike to me; which ever you pleaſe, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: What a deal of ceremony!—how cool they are about it.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: And why not cool, Sir; why not cool?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: O, very true—I am ſure it has froze me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
I will go inſtantly, for fear it ſhou'd
ſlip my memory, and put this paper into the hands of proper officers—in the mean time, Sir Luke, if you can talk with your viſitor, Mr. Twineall, do—inquire his opinion of the Sultan's rights—aſk his thoughts, as if you were commiſſioned by me—and, while he is revealing them to you, the officers ſhall be in ambuſh, ſurpriſe him in the midſt of his ſentiments, and bear him away to—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: May I preſume to inquire how your Ladyſhip does?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, yes—and pray walk in—I am quite recovered.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Lady Tremor, I bid you good day for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Following him to the door.]
sp.p: Your Lordſhip won't forget?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: No—depend upon it, I ſhall remember.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Yes—and make ſome other people remember too.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Is his Lordſhip gone? I am very ſorry.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No—don't be uneaſy, he'll ſoon be back.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Mr. Haſwell, I am glad to ſee you?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I told her Ladyſhip I would call in the evening, Sir Luke; and ſo I have kept my word—I wanted too to ſpeak with my Lord Flint, but he was in ſuch a hurry as he paſſed me, he wou'd hardly let me aſk him how he did.—I hope your Ladyſhip is well this afternoon.

div.stage: [Bows to Twineall—Sir Luke exit at the door to Aurelia and Elvirus.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
Pardon me, Mr. Haſwell, but I almoſt ſuſpect you heard of her Ladyſhip's indiſpoſition,
and therefore paid this viſit; for I am not to learn your care and attention to all under affliction.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [Bows gravely.]
sp.p: Has your Ladyſhip been indiſpoſed then?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A little—but I am much better.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Surely, of all virtues, charity is the firſt! it ſo protects our neighbour!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Do not you think, Sir, patience frequently protects him as much?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Dear Sir—pity for the poor miſerable—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Is oftener excited than the poor and miſerable are aware of.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [From the room where Aurelia and Elvirus are.]
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I beg you will walk into this apartment—Aurelia, introduce the gentleman to Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Who has ſhe with her?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Aurelia!—O! I have not ſeen her I know not when—and beſides my acquaintance with her relations in England, there is a frank ſimplicity about her that—

div.stage: Enter Sir Luke, Aurelia, and Elvirus.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: You ſhou'd have introduced the gentleman before—I aſſure you, Sir, [To Elvirus.] I did not know, nor ſhou'd I have known, if I had not accidently come into the room.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [To Lady Tremor.]
sp.p: A relation of Aurelia's—a Mr. Glanmore, my dear, juſt arrived from England; who call'd to paſs a few minutes with us, before he ſets off to the part of India he is to reſide in.
sp.stage: [Elvirus and Aurelia appear in the utmoſt embarraſſment and confuſion.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, your ſtay with us will not be ſo ſhort as Sir Luke has mentioned?

sp.speaker: Elv,
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, it muſt—the caravan, with which I travel, goes off this evening, and I muſt accompany it.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [Aſide.]
sp.p: I doubted before; but the voice confirms me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, you only arrived this morning, did you, Mr. Glanmore? you came paſſenger in the ſame ſhip, then, with Mr. Twineall?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No, Madam—Sir, I am very ſorry we had not the pleaſure of your company on board of us.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: You had:—Mr. Glanmore came over in the Mercury—did not you tell me ſo, Sir?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul, Sir! I beg your pardon—but ſurely that cannot be—I got acquainted with every ſoul on board of us—every creature—all their connections—and I can ſcarcely ſuppoſe you were of the number.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Aſide.]
sp.p: How impertinent he is to this gentleman too! O! that I had but courage to knock him down.

sp.speaker: Elv. [To Twineall.]
sp.p: Perhaps, Sir—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Yes, I dare ſay, that was the caſe.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: What was the caſe, Madam?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Wha—wha—wha— [Mimicks.] that is not good breeding.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Why do you bluſh, Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Becauſe [Heſitating.] this gentleman——came over in the ſame ſhip with Mr. Twineall.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And I cant't ſay I wonder at your biuſhing.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why then poſitively, Sir, I thought I had known every paſſenger—and ſurely—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Mr. Twineall, your behaviour puts me out of all patience—did you not hear the gentleman
man ſay he came in the ſame veſſel; and is not that ſufficient?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Perfectly, Madam—perfectly—but I thought there might be ſome miſtake.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And there is, Sir—you find you are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I thought ſo,——

sp.speaker: Haſ.[To Elvirus.]
sp.p: And you did come in the ſame veſſel?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Sir, do you doubt it?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Doubt it?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Dare not doubt it.—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Dare not?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No, Sir, dare not.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh, heavens!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.[To Aurelia.]
sp.p: Come, my dear, you and I will get out of the way.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O, dear!—for heaven's ſake!—Mr. Twineall, this is your doing.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Me, Madam!——

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I beg the company's pardon—but [To Elvirus.] a ſingle word with you, Sir, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Haſwell——

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Truſt my prudence and forbearance, Madam—I will but ſpeak a word in private to this gentleman.—
sp.stage: [Haſwell takes Elvirus down to the bottom of the ſtage; the reſt retire.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Are you, or are you not, an impoſtor?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I am—I am—but do not you repeat my words—Do not you ſay it.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What am I to fear?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Fear me—I cannot lie with fortitude; but I can——Beware of me.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I will beware of you, and ſo ſhall all my friends.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Inſolent, inſulting man.—

div.stage: Lady Tremor and the reſt come down.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, come, gentlemen, I hope you are now perfectly ſatisfied about this little nonſenſe.—Let us change the ſubject.—Mr. Haſwell, have you been ſucceſsful before the Sultan for any of thoſe poor priſoners you viſited this morning?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Ave; Meanright told me he ſaw you coming from them with your long cloak; and ſaid he ſhou'd not have known you, if ſomebody had not ſaid it was you.

div.stage: [Elvirus looks with ſurpriſe, confuſion, and repentance.]

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But what ſucceſs with the Sultan?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: He has granted me the pardon and freedom of any ſix I ſhall preſent as objects of his mercy.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I ſincerely rejoice.—Then the youth and his father, whom you felt ſo much for, I am ſure, will be in the number of thoſe who ſhare your clemency.

div.stage: [Haſwell makes no reply, and after a pauſe]—

sp.speaker: Elv. [With the moſt ſupplicatory tone and manner.]
sp.p: Sir—Mr. Haſwell—O, heavens!

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Come, Mr. Haſwell, this young man ſeems ſorry he has offended you—forgive him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Aye, do, Mr. Haſwell—are you ſorry, Sir?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: O! wounded to the heart—and, without his pardon, ſee nothing but deſpair.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good heavens!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Sir Luke, my Lord Flint told me he was coming back directly—pray inform him I had buſineſs elſewhere, and cou'd wait no longer.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: O! I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Follow him, if you have any thing to ſay?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I dare not—I feel the terror of his juſt reproach.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Did you know him in England?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Dear Madam, will you ſuffer me to ſpeak a few words——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Aye; leave her and her relation together, and let us take a turn in the garden with Mr. Twineall.—I'm afraid his Lordſhip will be back before we have drawn him to ſay more on the ſubject, for which he will be arreſted.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Mr. Twineall, will you walk this way?—That young lady and gentleman wiſh to have a little converſation.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
O, certainly, Sir Luke, by all means. [Exeunt Sir Luke and Lady.
[To Elvirus.] I am extremely ſorry, Sir, you kept your bed during the voyage: I ſhou'd elſe have been moſt prodigiouſly happy in ſuch good company.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why are you thus agitated? It was wrong to be ſo impetuous—but ſuch regret as this——

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Hear the ſecret I refuſed before—my father is a priſoner for life.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Oh, heavens! then Mr. Haſwell was the only man——

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And he had promiſed me—promiſed me, with benevolence, his patronage—but the diſguiſe he wore when I firſt ſaw him, led me to miſtake him now—made me expoſe my falſehood, my infamy, and treat his honour'd perſon with abuſe.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
Aye; let his virtues make you thus repent;
but let them alſo make you hope forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Nay, he is juſt, as well as compaſſionate—and for detected falſehood—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: You make me tremble.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Yet he ſhall hear my ſtory—I'll follow him, and obtain his pity, if not his pardon.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Nay, ſupplicate for that too—and you need not bluſh, or feel yourſelf degraded, to kneel to HIM, for he wou'd ſcorn the pride that triumphs over the humbled.

div.head: SCENE II. The Garden.
div.stage: Enter Sir Luke, Twineall, and Lady Tremor.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir Luke, as my Lord has given you charge to ſound my prineiples, I muſt own they are juſt ſuch as I delivered to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Twineall, I only wiſh you to be a little more clear—we will ſuppoſe the preſent Sultan no impoſtor—yet what pretenſions do you think the other family—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: That I'll make clear to you at once—or if my reaſons are not very clear, they are at leaſt very poſitive, and that you know is the ſame thing.—This family—no—that family—the family that reigned before this—this came after that—they came before. Now every one agrees that this family was always—ſo and ſo— [whiſpering.]—and that the other was always—ſo and ſo— [whiſpering.]—in ſhort, every body knows that one of them had always a very ſuſpicious—you know what——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No, I don't.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p:
Pſhaw—pſhaw—every body conjectures what—and though it was never ſaid in ſo many
words, yet it was always ſuppoſed—and though there never has been any proof, yet there have been things much more ſtrong—and for that very reaſon, Sir William—(Sir Luke, I mean—I beg your pardon)—for that very reaſon—(I can't think what made me call you Sir William)—for that very reaſon—(Oh, I was thinking of Sir William Tiffany)—for that very reaſon, ſay people what they will—that, that muſt be their opinion—but then where is the man who will ſpeak his thoughts freely as I have done?

div.stage: Enter Guards, who had been liſtening at a diſtance during this ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke. [Starting.]
sp.p: Bleſs my ſoul, gentlemen, you made my heart jump to my very lips.

sp.speaker: Guard. [To Twineall.]
sp.p: Sir, you are our priſoner, and muſt go with us.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are miſtaken—I had all my clothes made in England, and 'tis impoſſible the bill can have followed me already.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Your charge, is ſomething againſt the ſtate.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Againſt the ſtate?—You are miſtaken—it cannot be me.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: No—there is no miſtake.— [Pulling out a paper.]—You are here called Henry Twineall.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But if they have left out honourable, it can't be me——I am the Honourable Henry Twineall.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Aye, that you are to prove before your judges.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—and we are witneſſes of the long ſpeech you have juſt now been making.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And pray, gentlemen, did you know what I meant by it?

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, then, upon my ſoul, it was more than I did—I wiſh I may be ſacrificed——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Well, well, you are going to be ſacrificed—Don't be impatient.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But, gentlemen—Sir Luke!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Twineall, I am afraid you will have occaſion for the dignity of all my anceſtors to ſupport you under this trial.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And have occaſion for all my courage too.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But, Sir—but, gentlemen——

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Oh! I wou'd not be in your coat, faſhionable as it is, for all the Sultan's dominions.

div.stage: [Exit Sir Luke and Lady—Twineall, and Guards—ſeparately.

div.head: SCENE I. The Priſon.
div.stage: Haſwell and the female Priſoner diſcovered.

sp.speaker: Haſwell.
sp.p: RATHER remain in this loathſome priſon!—refuſe the bleſſing offered you!—the bleſſing your pleaſed fancy formed ſo precious you durſt not even truſt its reality!

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: No—while my pleaſed fancy only ſaw the proſpect, I own it was delightful; but now reaſon beholds it within my reach, the view is changed—and what, in the gay dream of fond delirium, ſeemed a bleſſing, in my waking hours of ſad reflection would prove the moſt ſevere of puniſhments.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Explain—what is the cauſe that makes you think thus?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: A cauſe that has alone for fourteen years made me reſigned to a fate like this.—When you firſt mentioned my releaſe from this drear place, my wild ideas included, with the light, all that had ever made the light a bleſſing—'twas not the ſun I ſaw in my mad tranſport, but a loſt huſband filled my roving fancy—'twas his idea that gave the colours of the world their beauty, and made me fondly hope to graſp its ſweets.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: A huſband!

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p:
But the world that I was wont to enjoy
with him—to ſee again without him—every wellknown object would wound my mind with dear remembrances for ever loſt, and make my freedom torture.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: But yet—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Oh! on my knees a thouſand times I have thanked Heaven that he partook not of this dire abode—that he ſhared not with me my hard uſage!—a greater bleſſing I poſſeſs'd from that, than all his loved ſociety cou'd have given—but in a happy world, where ſmiling nature pours her boundleſs gifts!—oh! there his loſs wou'd be unſufferable.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Do you lament him dead?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Yes—or, like me, a priſoner—elſe he wou'd have ſought me out—have ſought his Arabella!— [Haſwell ſtarts.]—Why do you ſtart?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Are you a Chriſtian?—an European?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: The name made me ſuppoſe it.—I am ſhocked that—the Chriſtian's ſufferings— [Trying to conceal his ſurpriſe.]—but were you made a priſoner in the preſent Sultan's reign?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Yes, or I had been ſet free on his aſcent to the throne; for he gave pardon to all the enemies of the ſlain monarch: but I was taken in a veſſel, where I was hurried in the heat of the battle with a party of the late Emperor's friends—and all the priſoners were by the officers of the preſent Sultan ſent to ſlavery, or confined, as I have been, in hopes of ranſom from their friends.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: And did never intelligence or inquiry reach you from your huſband?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Never?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p:
I once was informed of a large reward for the diſcovery of a female Chriſtian, and, with
boundleſs hopes, aſked an interview with the meſſenger; but found, on inquiry, I could not anſwer his deſcription, as he ſecretly informed me it was the Sultan who made the ſearch for one he himſelf had known and dearly loved.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Good Heaven!— [Aſide.]—You then conclude your huſband dead?

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I do;—or, like me, by ſome miſchance, taken with the other party, and having no friend to plead his cauſe before the Emperor, whom he ſerved—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I'll plead it—ſhould I ever chance to find him—but, ere we can hope for other kindneſs, you muſt appear before the Sultan—thank him for the favour which you now decline, and tell the cauſe why you cannot accept it.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Alas! almoſt worn out with ſorrow—an object of affliction as I am—in pity, excuſe me—preſent my thanks—my humble gratitude—but pardon my attendance.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt go—it is neceſſary—I will accompany you to him.—Retire a moment; but when I ſend, be ready.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: I ſhall obey

div.stage: [As Haſwell comes down, Elvirus places himſelf in his path—Haſwell ſtops, looks at him with an auſtere earneſtneſs, which Elvirus obſerving, turns away his face.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Nay, reproach me—I can bear your anger, but do not let me meet your eye—Oh! it is more awful, now I know who you are, than if you had kingdoms to diſperſe, or could deal inſtant death.— [Haſwell looks on him with a manly firmneſs, then walks on, Elvirus following him.]—I do not plead for my father now.—Since what has paſſed, I only aſk forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Do you forgive yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: I never will.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: One of our priſoners, who, in his cell, makes the moſt pitious moans, has ſent to entreat that Mr. Haſwell will not leave this place till he has heard his complaints and ſupplications.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Bring me to him.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: Nay, leave me not thus—perhaps never to ſee you more!—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee me again—in the mean time, reflect on what you merit.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: And what is that?—Confuſion!—and yet, he ſays, I am to ſee him again—ſpeak with him.—Oh! there's a bleſſing to the moſt abandoned, a divine propenfity (they know not why) to commune with the virtuous!

div.head: SCENE II. The firſt Priſon Scene.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Where is the poor unfortunate?

sp.speaker: 2d Keep.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Am I to behold greater miſery ſtill?—a ſtill greater object of compaſſion?

div.stage: [Second Keeper opens a door, and Twineall enters a priſoner, in one of the priſon dreſſes.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Don't you know me, Mr. Haſwell?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir—I beg your pardon—but is it?—is it?—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Haſwell—if you don't know me, or won't know me, I ſhall certainly loſe my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: O, I know you—know you very well.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: What, notwithſtanding the alteration in my dreſs?—there was a hard thing!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: O, I'll procure you that again—and, for all things elſe, I'm ſure you will have patience.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, no, I can't—upon my ſoul I can't.—I want a little lavender water—My hair is in ſuch a trim too!—No powder—no bruſhes—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I will provide you with them all.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But who will you provide to look at me, when I am dreſs'd?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I'll bring all your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I had rather you wou'd take me to ſee them.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Haſwell!—Dear Sir!—Dear friend!—What ſhall I call you?—Only ſay what title you like beſt, and I'll call you by it directly—I always did love to pleaſe every body—and I am ſure at this time I ſtand more in need of a friend than ever I did in my life.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What has brought you here?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Typing to get a place.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: A place?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Yes; and you ſee I have got one—and a poor place it is!—in ſhort, Sir, my crime is ſaid to be an offence againſt the ſtate; and they tell me no friend on earth but you can get that remitted.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Upon my word, the pardons I have obtained are for ſo few perſons—and thoſe already promiſed—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O, I know I am no favourite of yours—you think me an impertinent, ſilly, troubleſome fellow, and that my conduct in life will be neither of uſe to my country nor of benefit to ſociety.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You miſtake me, Sir—I think ſuch glaring imperfections as yours are, will not be of ſo much diſadvantage to ſociety as thoſe of a leſsfaulty man.—In beholding your conduct, thouſands ſhall turn from the paths of folly, to which faſhion, cuſtom, nature, (or call it what you will) impels them;—therefore, Mr. Twineall, if not pity for your faults, yet a concern for the good effect they may have upon the world (ſhou'd you be admitted there again) will urge me to ſolicit your return to it.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Sir, you have ſuch powers of oratory—what a prodigious capital quality!—and I doubt not but you are admired by the world equally for that—

sp.speaker: Meſſ
sp.p: Sir, the Sultan is arrived in the council chamber, and has ſent me.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I come.—Mr. Twineall, farewell for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Now, what was that whiſper about?—Oh, heavens! perhaps my death in agitation.—I have brought myſelf into a fine ſituation!—done it by wheedling too!

sp.speaker: 2d Keep.
sp.p: Come, your buſineſs with Mr. Haſwell being ended, return to your cell.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Certainly, Sir—certainly!—O, yes!—How happy is this priſon in having ſuch a keeper as you!—ſo mild, ſo gentle—there is ſomething about you,—I ſaid, and I thought the moment I had the happineſs of meeting you here,—Dear me!—what wou'd one give for ſuch a gentleman as him in England!—You wou'd be of infinite ſervice to ſome of our young bucks, Sir.

sp.speaker: 2d Keep.
sp.p: Go to your cell—go to your cell.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: This world wou'd be nothing without elegant manners, and elegant people in all ſtations of life.— [Enter Meſſenger, who whiſpers ſecond Keeper.]—Another whiſper!

sp.speaker: 2d Keep.
sp.p: No; come this way.—The judge is now ſtting in the hall, and you muſt come before him.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Before the judge, Sir—O, dear Sir!—what, in this deſhabille?—in this coat?—Dear me!—but to be ſure one muſt conform to cuſtoms—to the cuſtom of the country where one is.— [He goes to the door, and then ſtops.]—I beg your pardon, Sir—wou'd not you chufe to go firſt?

sp.speaker: 2d Keep.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: O!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Sultan, I have out-run your bountry in my promiſes; and one poor, unhappy female——

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: No—you named yourſelf the number to releaſe, and it is fixed—I'll not increaſe it.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: A poor, miſerable female——

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Am I leſs miſerable than ſhe is?—And who ſhall releaſe me from my ſorrows?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Then let me tell you, Sultan, ſhe is above your power to oblige, or to puniſh.—Ten years, nay more, confinement in a drear cell has been no greater puniſhment to her, than had ſhe lived in a pleaſant world without the man ſhe loved.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: And freedom offered ſhe rejects with ſcorn, becauſe he is not included in the bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: You talk of prodigies!— [He makes a ſign for the Guards to retire, and they exit.]—and yet I once knew a heart equal to this deſcription.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Nay, will you ſee her?—Witneſs yourſelf the fact?

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Why do I tremble?—My buſy fancy preſents an image——

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Yes, tremble, indeed!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Hah! have a care—what tortures are you preparing for me?—My mind ſhrinks at the idea.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Your wife you will behold—whom you have kept in want, in wretchedneſs, in a damp dungeon, for theſe fourteen years, becauſe you wou'd not liſten to the voice of piry.——Dread her look—her frown—not for herſelf alone, but for hundreds of her fellow ſufferers—and while your ſelfiſh fancy was ſearching, with wild anxiety, for her you loved, unpitying, you forgot others might love like you.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: O! do not bring me to a trial which I have not courage to ſupport.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: She attends without—I ſent for her to thank you for the favour ſhe declines.—Nay, be compoſed—ſhe knows you not—cannot, thus diſguiſed as the Sultan.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Oh! my Arabella! could I have thought that your approach wou'd ever impreſs my mind with horror!—or that, inſtead of flying to your arms with all the love I bear you, terror and dread ſhou'd fix me a ſtatue of remorſe.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Here kneel, and return your thanks.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: My Arabella! worn with grief and anguiſh!

sp.speaker: Ara. [Kneeling to the Sultan.]
sp.p:
Sultan, the favour
you wou'd beſtow, I own, and humbly thank you for.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Gracious Heaven!

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: But as I am now accuſtomed to confinement, and the idea of all the world can give, cannot inſpire a wiſh that warms my heart to the enjoyment—I ſupplicate permiſſion to transfer the bleſſing you have offered, to one of thoſe who may have friends to welcome their return from bondage, and ſo make freedom precious.—I have none to rejoice at my releaſe—none to lament my deſtiny while a priſoner.—And were I free, in this vaſt world (forlorn and friendleſs) 'tis but a priſon ſtill.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: What have I done?—
sp.stage: [Throwing himſelf on a ſopha with the greateſt emotion.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Speak to him again.—He repents of the ſeverity with which he has cauſed his fellow creatures to be uſed.—Tell him you forgive him.

sp.speaker: Ara. [Going to him.]
sp.p: Believe me, Emperor, I forgive all who have ever wronged me—all who have ever cauſed my ſufferings.—Pardon you!—Alas! I have pardoned even thoſe who tore me from my huſband!—Oh, Sultan! all the tortures you have made me ſuffer, compared to ſuch a pang as that—did I ſay I had forgiven it?—Oh! I am afraid—afraid I have not yet.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Forgive it now, then, for he is reſtored.— [Taking off his turban.]—Behold him in the Sultan, and once more ſeal his pardon.— [She faints on Haſwell.]—Nay, pronounce it quickly, or my remorſe for what you have undergone, will make my preſent tortures greater than any my cruelties have ever yet inflicted.

sp.speaker: Ara. [Recovering]
sp.p:
Is this the light you promiſed?— [To Haſwell.]—Dear precious light!—Is this my freedom? to which I bind myſelf a
flave for ever.— [Embracing the Sultan.]—Was I your captive?—Sweet captivity!—more precious than an age of liberty!

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: Oh, my Arabella! through the amazing changes of my fate, (which I will ſoon diſcloſe) think not but I have ſearched for thee with unceaſing care; but the bleſſing to behold you once again was left for my kind monitor alone to beſtow.——Oh, Haſwell! had I, like you, made others' miſeries my concern, like you ſought out the wretched, how many days of ſorrow had I ſpared myſelf as well as others—for I long ſince had found my Arabella.

sp.speaker: Ara.
sp.p: Oh, Heaven! that weigheſt our ſufferings with our joys, and as our lives decline ſeeſt in the balance thy bleſſings far more ponderous than thy judgements—be witneſs, I complain no more of what I have endured, but find an ample recompence this moment.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I told you, Sir, how you might be happy.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p: —Take your reward—(to a heart like yours, more valuable than treaſure from my coffers)—this ſignet, with power to redreſs the wrongs of all who ſuffer.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Valuable indeed!——

sp.speaker: Ara. [To Haſwell.]
sp.p: Oh, virtuous man!—to reward thee are we made happy—to give thy pitying boſom the joy to ſee us ſo, has Heaven remitted its intended puniſhment of continued ſeparation.

sp.speaker: Sul.
sp.p:
Come, my beloved wife!—come to my palace—there, equally, my deareſt bleſſing, as when the cottage gave its fewer joys—and in him [To Haſwell.] we not only find our preſent happineſs, but dwell ſecurely on our future hopes—for here, I vow, before he leaves our ſhores, I will adopt every meaſure he ſhall point out—and that period of my life whereon he ſhall lay his cenſure,
that will I fix apart for penitence.—
sp.stage: [Exit Sultan and Arabella.—Haſwell bows to Heaven with thanks.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: An Engliſh priſoner, juſt now condemned to loſe his head, one Henry Twineall, humbly begs permiſſion to ſpeak a few ſhort ſentences, his laſt dying words, to Mr. Haſwell.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Condemned to loſe his head?—Lead me to him.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: O, Sir, you need not hurry yourſelf—it is off by this time, I dare ſay.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Off?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—we don't ſtand long about theſe things in this country—I dare ſay it is off.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [Impatiently.]
sp.p: Lead me to him inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.p: O! 'tis of conſequence, is it, Sir?—if that is the caſe——

div.head: SCENE IV. An arch-way at the top of the ſtage, through which ſeveral Guards enter—Twineall in the middle, dreſſed for execution, with a large book in his hand.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: One more verſe, gentlemen, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: The time is expired.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: One more, gentlemen, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: The time is expired.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Oh! my dear Mr. Haſwell!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: What, in tears at parting with me?—This is a compliment indeed!

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I hope you take it as ſuch—I am ſure I mean it as ſuch.—It kills me to leave you—it breaks my heart;—and I once flattered myſelf ſuch a charitable, good, feeling, humane heart as you poſſeſs—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Hold! Hold!—This, Mr. Twineall, is the vice which has driven you to the fatal precipice whereon you are—and in death will you not relinquiſh it?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: What vice, Sir, do you mean?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Flattery!—a vice that renders you not only deſpicable, but odious.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: But how has flattery been the cauſe?

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Your Engliſh friend, before he left the iſland, told me what information you had aſked from him, and that he had given you the direct oppoſite of every perſon's character, as a juſt puniſhment for your mean premeditation and deſigns.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I never imagined that amiable friend had ſenſe enough to impoſe upon any body!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Yet I preſume, he could not ſuppoſe fate would have carried their reſentment to a length like this.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Oh! cou'd fate be arreſted in its courſe!

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: You wou'd reform your conduct?

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I wou'd—I wou'd never ſay another civil thing to any body—never—never make myſelf agreeable again.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Releaſe him—here is the Sultan's ſignet.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Oh! my dear Mr. Haſwell! never was compaſſion!—never benevolence!—never ſuch a heart as yours!—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Sieze him—he bas broken his contract already.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No, Sir—No, Sir—I proteſt you are an illnatured, ſurly, crabbed fellow. I always thought ſo, upon my word, whatever I have ſaid.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: And, I'll forgive that meaning, ſooner than the other—utter any thing but flattery—Oh! never let the honeſt, plain, blunt Engliſh name, become a proverb for ſo baſe a vice.—

sp.speaker: Lady Ter. [Without.]
sp.p: Where is the poor creature?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh! if his head is off, pray let me look at it?—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: No, Madam, it is on—and I am very happy to be able to tell you ſo.—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dear Heaven!—I expected to have ſeen it off!—but no matter—as it is on—I am come that it may be kept on—and have brought my Lord Flint, and Sir Luke, as witneſſes.

div.stage: Enter Lord, Aurelia, and Sir Luke.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Well, Madam, and what have they to ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Who are we to tell our ſtory to?—There does not ſeem to be any one ſitting in judgement.—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: Tell it to me, Sir—I will report it.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Why then, Mr. Haſwell, as Ghoſts ſometimes walk—and as one's conſcience is ſometimes troubleſome—I think Mr. Twineall has done nothing to merit death, and the charge which his Lordſhip ſent in againſt him, we begin to think too ſevere—but, if there was any falſe ſtatement—

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
It was the fault of my not charging my
memory—any error I have been guilty of, muſt be laid to the fault of my total want of memory.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: And what do you hope from this confeſfion?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: To remit the priſoner's puniſhment of death to ſomething leſs, if the Sultan will pleaſe to annul the ſentence

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Yes—and grant ten or twelve years impriſonment—or the Gallies for fourteen years—or—

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: Ay, ay, ſomething in that way.

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: For ſhame—for ſhame—Gentlement!—the extreme rigour you ſhew in puniſhing a diſſenſion from your opinion, or a ſatire upon your folly, proves to conviction, what reward you had beſtowed upon the ſkilful flatterer.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies, pray why wou'd you wiſh me requited with ſuch extreme ſeverity, merely for my humble endeavours to make myſelf agreeable?—Lady Tremor, upon my honour I was credibly informed, your anceſtors were Kings of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Impoſſible!—you might as well ſay that you heard Sir Luke had diſtinguiſhed himſelf at the battle of—

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And, I did hear ſo

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And he did diſtinguiſh himſelf; for he was the only one that ran away.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Cou'd it happen?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, it did happen.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: And go you, Mr. Twineall, into a field of battle, and I think it is very likely to happen again.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p:
If Mr. Haſwell has obtained your pardon, Sir, it is all very well—but let me adviſe you to keep your ſentiments on politics to yourſelf,
for the future—as you value that pretty head of yours.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir—I do value it.

sp.speaker: Haſ. [Going to him.]
sp.p: Aurelia, in this letter to me, has explained your ſtory with ſo much compaſſion, that, for her ſake, I muſt pity it too.—With freedom to your father, and youſelf, the Sultan reſtores his forfeited lands—and might I plead, Sir Luke, for your intereſt with Aureila's friends, this young man's filial love, ſhou'd be repaid by conjugal affection.

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: As for that, Mr. Haſwell, you have ſo much intereſt at court, that your taking the young man under you protection—beſides, as Aurelia was ſent hither merely to get a huſband—I don't ſee—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: True, Sir Luke—and I am afraid my father and mother will begin to be uneaſy that I have not got one yet—and I ſhou'd be very ſorry to diſobligethem.

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: No—ſay rather, ſorry to make me wretched.—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: My Indian friend, have you received your freedom?

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p: Yes—and come to bid you farewell—which I wou'd never do, had I not a family in wretchedneſs till my return—for you ſhou'd be my maſter, and I wou'd be your ſlave.—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I thank you—may you meet at home every comfort!

sp.speaker: Zed.
sp.p:
May you—may you—what ſhall I ſay?
—May you once in your life be a priſoner—then releaſed—to feel ſuch joy, as I feel now!—

sp.speaker: Haſ.
sp.p: I thank you for a wiſh, that tells me moſt emphatically, how much you think I have ſerved you.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: And, my dear Lord, I ſincerely wiſh you may once in your life, have your head chopped off—juſt to know what I ſhou'd have felt, in that fituation.—

sp.speaker: Zed. [Pointing to Haſwell.]
sp.p: Are all his countrymen as good as he?

sp.speaker: Sir Luke.
sp.p: No-no no-no—not all—but the worſt of them are good enough to admire him.

sp.speaker: Twi.
sp.p: Pray Mr. Haſwell, will you ſuffer all theſe encomiums?

sp.speaker: Elv.
sp.p: He muſt ſuffer them—there are virtues, which praiſe cannot taint—ſuch are Mr. Haſwell's—for they are the offspring of a mind, ſuperior even to the love of fame—neither can they, through malice, ſuffer by applauſe, ſince they are too ſacred to incite envy, and muſt conciliate the reſpect, the love, and the admiration of all.

lg.l: SINCE all are ſprung, they ſay, from Mother Earth,
Why ſtamp a merit or diſgrace on birth?
Yet ſo it is, however we diſguiſe it,
All boaſt their origin, or elſe deſpiſe it.
This pride or ſhame haunts ev'ry living ſoul
From Hyde-park Corner, down to Limehouſe Hole:
Peers, taylors, poets, ſtateſmen, undertakers,
Knights, ſquires, man-milliners, and peruke-makers.
Sir Hugh Glengluthglin, from the land of goats,
Tho' out at elbows, ſhews you all his coats;
And rightful heir to twenty pounds per annum,
Boaſts the rich blood that warm'd his great great grannam;
While wealthy Simon Soapſuds; juſt be-knighted,
Struck with the ſword of ſtate, is grown dim ſighted,
Forgets the neighbouring chins he uſed to lather,
And ſcarecely knows he ever had a father.
Our Author, then, correct in every line,
From nature's characters hath pictur'd mine;
For many a lofty fair, who, friz'd and curl'd,
With creſt of horſe hair, tow'ring thro' the world,
To powder, paſte, and pins, ungrateful grown,
Thinks the full periwig is all her own;
Proud of her conquering ringlets, onward goes,
Nor thanks the barber, from whoſe hands ſhe roſe.
Thus doth falſe pride fantaſtic minds miſlead,
And make our weaker ſex ſeem weak indeed:
Suppoſe, to prove this truth, in mirthful ſtrain,
We bring the Dripping family again.—
Papa, a tallow chandler by deſcent,
Had read "how larning is moſt excellent:"
So Miſs, returned from boarding ſchool at Bow,
Waits to be finiſhed by Mama and Co.—
"See, ſpouſe, how ſpruce our Nan is grown, and tall;
"I'll lay, ſhe cuts a daſh at Lord Mayor's ball."—
In bolts the maid—" Ma'am! Miſs's maſter's come;"—
Away fly Ma' and Miſs to dancing room—
"Walk in Mounſeer; come, Nan, draw up like me."—
"Ma fo • ! Madame, Miſs like you as two pea."—
Mounſeer takes out his kit; the ſcene begins;
Miſs truſſes up; my lady Mother grins;—
"Ma'amſelle, me teach a you de ſtep to tread;
"Firſt turn you toe, den turn you littel bead;
"One, two, dree, ſinka, riſa, balance; bon,
"Now entrechat, and new de cotillon.
"Pardieu, Ma'amſelle be one enchanting girl;
"Me no ſurpriſe to ſee her ved an Earl."—
"With all my heart, ſays Miſs; Mounſeer, I'm ready;
"I dream'd laſt night, Ma, I ſhould be a Lady."
Thus do the Drippings, all important grown,
Expect to ſhine with luſtre not their own;
New airs are got, freſh graces, and freſh waſhes,
New caps, new gauze, new feathers, and new ſaſhes;
Till juſt complete for conqueſt at Guildhall.
Down comes an order to ſuſpend the ball.
Miſs Shrieks, Ma' ſcolds, Pa' ſeems to have loſt his tether;
Caps, cuſtards, coronets—all ſink together—
Papa reſumes his jacket, dips away,
And Miſs lives ſingle, till next Lord Mayor's day.
If ſuch the ſorrow, and if ſuch the ſtrife,
That break the comforts of domeſtic life,
Look to the hero, who this night appears,
Whoſe boundleſs excellence the World reveres;
Who, friend to nature, by no blood confin'd,
Is the glad relative of all mankind.
